header.abstract: The Billye M. Peeples papers (dated 1895-2020, undated; 4.62 cubic feet; 16 boxes) comprise records for Order of Eastern Star and Heroines of Jericho, Prince Hall Affiliated, Jurisdiction of Kentucky collected by Past Worthy Matron, Billye M. Peeples, member of Dorcas Chapter No. 29, Lexington, Kentucky.

descriptive_summary.author: Ida Lucille Sell Mangum
descriptive_summary.title: Billye Peeples papers
descriptive_summary.creator: Peeples, Billye M.
descriptive_summary.arrangement: Collection is arranged by subject and format in six series: Heroines of Jericho, Order of Eastern Star, Personal papers and scrapbook, Photographs and realia, Phyllis Chapter of the Phylaxis Society, Scottish Rite, Shrine, and other auxiliaries.

descriptive_summary.prefercite: 2021ms004: [identification of item], Billye Peeples papers, 1895-2020, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The first masonic lodge for Black Kentuckians formed in 1850, with a group of men led by Jesse Meriweather and Reverend Bird Parker of Quinn Chapel AME and led by. At first, it was unsafe for a large gathering of Black men to meet at once in Kentucky, therefore the first lodge met in New Albany, Indiana. By 1854 the lodge had moved to a location on Walnut Street in Louisville. Today, the Most Worshipful Prince Hall Grand Lodge of Kentucky has sixty-nine subordinate lodges throughout the state.

The Order of the Eastern Star is a worldwide fraternal organization that is open to both men and women. Membership, however, is open to men who are Masons and women who are the wives, daughter, sisters, of Masons. The fundamental principles of the Order are based on the teachings of the Bible, but the Order welcomes followers of all religions if they have a belief in a Supreme Being. The organization's stated purposes are: Charitable, Educational, Fraternal, and Scientific.

In 1885 the first chapter instituted of the Order of Eastern Star for African Americans was Queen Esther No. 1 in Washington D.C. In 1893, the Most Worshipful Grand Master of Prince Hall Free and Accepted Masons in Kentucky, Charles Steele, in Georgetown, Kentucky, wrote a declaration that Adoptive Rites extended to mothers, wives, sisters, and daughters would enhance the Craft in the authority of Kentucky. In 1895, Prince Hall in Kentucky instituted a Grand Chapter of the Order of Eastern Star. Under its current name, the Cecelia Dunlap Grand Chapter, Alpha Chapter of the Order of Eastern Star, Jurisdiction of Kentucky, was chartered in 1922 in Midway, Kentucky. During its history, the Grand Chapter's dues have contributed to masonic relief funds and for a time to the operation of a Masonic Widows and Orphans Home in Buechel, Kentucky.

In 1895, there were eight Order of Eastern Star, Prince Hall Affiliated chapters in Kentucky, including Deborah No. 1 in Lexington, Kentucky. The first retained minutes for the Grand Chapter are from the Annual Communication in 1901. Dorcas Chapter No. 29, Lexington, Kentucky, is included as an existing chapter in those first minutes. As early as 1908, the Colored Notes section of the Lexington Leader newspaper listed Dorcas Chapter monthly meetings. Dorcas Chapter No. 29 produced three Grand Matrons: Sister Mary B. Jones, Bessie Ballard, and Willie M. Taylor. Past Matrons include Sisters Mary Edna Berry, Polly Hockers, Jean Higgins, and Billye M. Peeples.

On March 10th, 1978, the Cecelia Dunlap Grand Chapter, Order of the Eastern Star, Prince Hall Affiliate, Jurisdiction of Kentucky gave dispensation authorizing the institution of the Heroines of Jericho for the state. The Heroines of Jericho is a degree conferred by Royal Arch Masons, their wives, mothers, widows, sisters, and daughters. Work toward the degree shares the Masonic purpose of promoting friendship and charity, relieving suffering, and promoting moral, social, spiritual, and intellectual self-improvement. Knights and Heroines have contributed to relief funds and paid dues to the Prince Hall, Jurisdiction of Kentucky. Clubs held the first meeting, like the Horeb Cyrus Club in 1979, and then the Omega Grand Court formed in 1980.

Billye Susan Morrow Peeples, born March 8, 1947, is a Past Most Ancient Matron for Order of Eastern Star, Heroines of Jericho, Omega Grand Court a part of Kentucky's Masonic Prince Phillip Hall. Peeples grew up in Lynch, Kentucky, the U.S. Coal and Coke Company (a subsidiary of U.S. Steel) coal company town. Her father, William Morrow, was a Second War World veteran and coal miner, and her mother, Dorothy L. Woods Morrow, was a head nurse at Lynch Medical Center and the first African American woman on the Lynch City Council. Billye Peeples moved to Lexington, Kentucky in the mid 1960s. She has one son, Porter Peeples, Jr. In Lexington, Ms. Peeples is a member of Shiloh Baptist Church.

Bille M. Peeples is a member of the Order of the Eastern Star Dorcas Chapter No. 29, Prince Hall Affiliation. She has served as Past Worthy Matron and Past District Deputy Grand Matron within the Order of Eastern Star. Peeples is also a member of the Omega Grand Court, Heroines of Jericho, Prince Hall Affiliation in Kentucky. She served as Past Ancient Matron and Past Most Ancient Grand Matron within Heroines of Jericho. Internationally she has served as Past Most Ancient Grand Matron of the General Conference of Grand Courts, Heroines of Jericho of United States and Bahamas, Inc.
Sources: Ballard, William Henry. 1950. History of Prince Hall Freemasonry in Kentucky. Lexington, Ky.: publisher not identified.
202ms004: Heroines of Jericho History in Kentucky, 1977-1979, Billye M. Peeples papers, 1895-2020, undated, University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

2021ms004: Cecelia Dunlap Grand Chapter OES PHA, A Bright Star: A Biography of Cecelia Dunlap by Mollie M. Bradley, GWM, after 1987, Billye M. Peeples papers, 1895-2020, undated, University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.
Colored Notes, Lexington-Leader, page 26, Sunday, April 12, 1908, accessed 2023 March 1, https://www.newspapers.com/clip/119949912/lexington-herald-leader/

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Billye M. Peeples papers (dated 1895-2020, undated; 4.62 cubic feet; 16 boxes) comprise records for Order of Eastern Star and Heroines of Jericho, Prince Hall Affiliated, Jurisdiction of Kentucky collected by Past Worthy Matron, Billye M. Peeples, member of Dorcas Chapter No. 29, Lexington, Kentucky. The records consist of meeting minutes, membership rolls, financial receipts, programs, ritual lessons/books, and communications across the jurisdiction. The collection includes publications for various masonic organizations under the Prince Hall umbrella like the Phylaxis Society Magazine, a quarterly journal focused on the history of the African American masons. The collection also includes realia from Annual Communications like tote bags and souvenir programs and photographs from many Kentucky and International Prince Hall Affiliated events.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Heroines of Jericho series (1977-2019, undated) comprises records for the Heroines of Jericho of the United States and Bahamas, Prince Hall Affiliates, Grand Courts, Jurisdiction of Kentucky. The records include member files, dues receipts, and communications for among courts such as Phyllis W. Tilley No. 1, Miriam Court No. 2, Bathsheba Court No. 3, and Jochebed Court No. 7, as well as the Omega Grand Court, Kentucky. The series files are grouped by court name and chronologically. The Heroines of Jericho series also includes books and reports on the history of the organization in Kentucky and internationally and souvenir programs from the General Grand Conference of Grand Courts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Order of Eastern Star series (1895-2019, undated) comprises records for the Order of Eastern Star, Prince Hall Affiliated (PHA), Jurisdiction of Kentucky. The series includes souvenir programs and official proceedings for the Annual Communication of the Cecelia Dunlap Grand Chapter, Order of Eastern Star (OES), and the Annual Grand Communication of the Most Worshipful Prince Hall Grand Lodge, Free and Ancient Masons of Kentucky, Inc. Significantly, the series includes publications by the Kentucky Grand Chapter of OES, PHA, as early as 1911. The series also contains meeting books and financial record books for the Dorcas Chapter No. 29, Order of Eastern Star, of Lexington, Kentucky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal papers and scrapbook (1962-2017, undated) comprises honor certificates given to Past Worthy Matron Billye M. Peeples. It also includes personal cards and letters sent to Peeples from other Eastern Star sisters and a funeral program for Past Worthy Matron, Jean M. Higgins of Dorcas Chapter No. 29. The series also includes a scrapbook of Prince Hall Affiliated, Jurisdiction of Kentucky records, keepsakes, and event photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographs and Realia series (1952-2008, undated) comprises photographs of Order of the Eastern and Heroines of Jericho, Prince Hall Affiliated, Jurisdiction of Kentucky chapter, district, and grand lodge meetings and events. The photographs also depict scenes and groups of people at International Communications events. The series also contains some artifacts like member badges and tote bags from Annual Communications.

did.unittitle: Phyllis Chapter, Blue Grass Auxiliary, Phylaxis Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Phyllis Chapter, Blue Grass Auxiliary, Phylaxis Society series (1988-2020, undated) contains records for the Phyllis Chapter of the Phylaxis Society in central Kentucky. The chapter focuses on sharing the history of Prince Hall Affiliated history through reports and publications. Also included in the series are issues of the Phyllis Magazine and Phylaxis Society Magazine.

did.unittitle: Scottish Rite, Shrine, and other auxiliaries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Scottish Rite, Shrine, and other auxiliaries series (1979-2020, undated) contains some records related to the Prince Hall Affiliated organizations in Kentucky. It also includes official publications and magazines of national masonic organizations. Notably, the series includes some records of the Daughters of Isis, a Prince Hall Affiliated Shrine for Black women.
